and track their progress. Feel free to ask us any questions about the Honors
Program.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:red'>Goal:</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black'>ICS H197 provides an opportunity for undergraduate honors students
in the Donald Bren School of Information and Computer Sciences to learn about
the research taking place in the School and to begin to get involved with this
research. The major purpose of this course is to help you learn what sort of
research is going on, which people do what, and how to get connected with a
research project. The course will also provide a general introduction to the
scientific and technical research enterprise, including the research
literature, how to give a successful technical talk, the responsible conduct of
research, research intellectual property, and research funding (<span
class=SpellE>grantsmanship</span> and entrepreneurship)</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>. Various
enrichment activities include a library-based introduction to searching the
research literature, faculty panel on improving your graduate school
applications, and the opportunity to practice and improve technical talk
presentation skills in a live talk to the class.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>One
of your major goals in this course is to gain an understanding of what research
is being pursued in the School and what areas might be of interest to you for
your project. This goal is <span class=GramE>crucial,</span> since it should
help you complete your next goal, selection of your faculty advisor. Remember
that the arrangement must be mutually acceptable, so there is no guarantee that
the first faculty member you talk to will say yes; it may be, for example, that
they have no suitable project in mind at the time you ask.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>It
is not imperative that you begin your research immediately next quarter if your
schedule for graduation allows you enough time. However, there are some
important advantages to starting fairly soon, and we encourage you to begin by
spring quarter. Starting early gives you more flexibility with regard to
finishing the rest of your degree requirements, especially if you want to
continue the research for more than two quarters. Also, students often find
that those faculty members who have supervised their honors research project
are good sources for letters of recommendation; they will be in the best
position to comment on your ability if you are well into your research project.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=left>

</span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:red'>Please Note:</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo4'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>(1)<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black'>Two types of students take this course: students
in the ICS Honors Program (ICSHP), and students in the <span class=SpellE>Campuswide</span>
Honors Program (CHP). In many ways the requirements are the same for both types
of students: you are to select a faculty advisor, do two or more quarters of
research with that advisor, and produce a report which is considered to be of
honors quality. However, students in the <span class=SpellE>Campuswide</span>
Honors Program should discuss their plans with counselors in the CHP, in order
to make sure that they are meeting the requirements of that program.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo4'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>(2)<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black'>We are in the process of transitioning the ICS
H197 class into a more flexible largely-online course oriented more along the
lines of "Introduction to Undergraduate Research."<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Please help develop and debug the new
format and content.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>We'll work out
the details as we go along.</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:red'>Class Setup:</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>This
course is graded Pass/Not Pass, and the principal formal requirement is that
you attend and participate. You must read (at least) one research paper by an
ICS faculty member, and attend (at least) one ICS research talk (see the ICS
Calendar for schedule; this is <u>in addition</u> to attending ICS-90).<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Some
of the class exercises may involve students giving feedback to fellow students,
and your active participation is necessary for everyone to get the most benefit
from this. Occasional absences are inevitable given busy schedules, and will be
excused on a case-by-case basis; make sure you sign the attendance sheet each
class period you attend.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:red'>ICS H198: Honors Research<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>To
complete the honors program you must do two quarters of independent, supervised
work (ICS 198) with your faculty advisor. (In some cases, your advisor might
ask you to take a graduate course to substitute for the first quarter.) Passing
the 198s does not necessarily guarantee successful completion of the honors
program, however. For the ICSHP, the thesis report on your honors work must be
certified by your faculty advisor and by the program advisor to be of honors
quality. (Again, students in the CHP should keep in touch with counselors in
that program about the requirements.)<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l6 level1 lfo2'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
font-weight:normal;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>   </span></span></span><![endif]><span
class=GramE><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>students</span></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'> majoring in
ICS or CS can count completion of two ICS H198s as one project course.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";color:black'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><u>Identify
</u></span></b><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>five grad schools you might apply
to.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>For each school, identify one
professor there with whom you might work.<o:p></o:p></span></u></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.25in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo14'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
color:#0033BB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Email <span style='color:black'>your
list to Dr. Lathrop by Wed., 29 Oct.</span><span style='color:#0033BB'><o:p></o:p></span></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-left:1.25in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo14'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
color:#0033BB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:#0033BB'>The reason for this requirement is so that when you write your
Statement of Purpose for each school, you will be able to mention at least one
professor<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> *from that school* </b>who
interests you.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-left:1.25in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo14'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
color:#0033BB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:#0033BB'>Some professors will do a global string search for their name
through all of the applicant's Statements of Purpose, and then preferentially
read those applications that mention their name.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.25in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo14'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
color:#0033BB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:#0033BB'>Thus, if you want to improve the chances that your application
actually will be read seriously, it is helpful to you to mention names of
professors at that school who interest you.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Of course, if you mention a long list of
names it will be obvious spam, so mention no more than one to three. Also, briefly
mention something personal that attracts your interest about each, again to
indicate that it isn’t just impersonal spam.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.25in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo14'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
color:#0033BB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:#0033BB'>These remarks apply mainly to Ph.D. applications.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>M.S. applications usually do not receive
as much carefully individual scrutiny as do Ph.D. applications.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.25in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo14'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
color:#0033BB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>  
</span></span></span><![endif]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";color:red'>Even if you currently do not
intend to apply to graduate school, you still must attend the Panel and do the
homework.</span></u></b><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";color:red'><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>If you ever change your mind later in
your career, after you know more than you do now, you will want to be properly
prepared.</span></b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";color:#0033BB'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>You learned the basics in

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span>*
Don’t lie:<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Don’t make
up false data or otherwise falsify results.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span>*
Don’t cheat:<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Don’t
misrepresent your data as something it is not or as better than it is.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span>*
Don’t steal:<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Don’t use
the words or data of others without proper credit and citation; don’t
plagiarize.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
4'>                                                </span></span></b><span
class=SpellE><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>GIDMaPS</span></span><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>: A Drought Time Machine [<a
href="talk-Momtaz-GIDMaPS.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></b></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>                                                </span>Drought
is defined as lack of water supplies and rainfall. During the recent years our
economy, ecosystem, and even human lives have been affected by its <span
class=SpellE>effects.The</span> Global Integrated Drought Monitoring and
Prediction System (<span class=SpellE>GIDMaPS</span>) is the first global
drought monitoring and prediction system that covers the globe with near
real-time resolution. It is also the first drought prediction system, which
automatically retrieves data from model simulations and satellite observations.
The monitoring component provides drought severity, while the prediction
component offers probability occurrence of drought for different severity
levels. Its ability to predict the future droughts can prevent millions in
economic loss, wild fires, and save human lives.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
2'>                        </span>12:25-12:50
--- Sean Dunn<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Title:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:.5in'><span class=SpellE><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>DDoS</span></span><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'> Attacks: A Real and Rising Concern [<a
href="talk-Dunn-DDoS%20Attacks.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>                                                </span>In
the past decade, <span class=SpellE>DDoS</span> attacks have grown immensely
popular among malicious hackers.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>A <span
class=SpellE>DDoS</span>, or Distributed Denial of Service, is a method by
which these malicious hackers can prevent users from accessing a certain
computer resource by overloading it with requests from an array of separate
computer systems.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>The targeted
resource becomes so busy responding to these empty requests that legitimate
users are unable to access the resource effectively.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>While a malicious virus or worm is a
precision tool designed for a specific purpose such as using a host machine to
send spam emails, a <span class=SpellE>DDoS</span> attack is a blunt weapon,
capable for disabling entire systems for hours or even days.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Its effectiveness can be seen in its
diverse use. Large scale <span class=SpellE>DDoS</span> attacks have affected
everyone from video game companies to financial institutions and even the CIA.</span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Title:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
4'>                                                </span></span></b><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>3D Non-rigid Objects Recognition Using
Laplace Beltrami <span class=SpellE>Eigensystem</span> [<a
href="talk-Jiao-3-D-Point-Clouds-Cluster.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></b></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>                                                </span>The
recognition of three-dimensional (3D) objects is a major interest in computer
vision. High-density point clouds provide an identification of object classes
such as dogs, cats, and horses. Since each point cloud system is of different
object classes, the non-rigid structures within the same object class can be
interrelated due to their intrinsically similar distribution. The talk will
address two approaches and solutions for recognition of non-rigid 3D objects
that exhibit a “pose invariance” property under 3D rotation. It is
difficult to infer the underlying class of a 3D model due to the lack of
correspondence between the original model and its intrinsic class. The
recognition of 3D models containing information inferring the underlying 3D
object class is difficult due to the lack of consistent and reliable
correspondences. The proposed approaches match and distinguish unordered 3D
non-rigid objects by preserving characteristics represented by LB <span
class=SpellE>eigen</span>-functions as well as eliminating noises via the
moment invariant method. The resulting cluster analysis is able to directly
match 3D deformable objects with its corresponding class and recognize
non-rigid deformable objects as different classes, thereby supporting
efficiency in the classification of unordered 3D models.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
2'>                        </span>12:25-12:50
--- <span class=SpellE>Weicheng</span> Yu<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Title:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:.5in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Crowdsourcing:
A new work style [<a href="talk-Yu-Crowdsourcing.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Crowdsourcing
is a relatively new term. It defines a process of obtaining services, ideas or content
by soliciting contributions from a group of people. The modern method transfers
crowdsourcing to the Internet. Contributors in a crowdsourcing project are
granted more freedom since they are not scrutinized by others physically. The
online environment tends to put less stress on people, allowing them to deliver
more creative works. Crowdsourcing is evolving quickly, and it is applied to
many more fields other than computer science related projects. More and more
people are embracing it as a new work style to the traditional work style.</span><span
class=MsoHyperlink><span style='color:windowtext;text-decoration:none;
text-underline:none'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:

3'>                                    </span>Title:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
4'>                                                </span></span></b><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>The distinction of Concurrency and Parallelism
[<a href="talk-Wu-Concurrency-is-NOT-parallelism.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></b></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>                                                </span>In
this talk, I reference Rob Pike’s Tech Talk on “Concurrency Is Not
Parallelism” and discuss the differences and similarities between concurrency
and parallelism. Concurrency is defined as the composition of independently
executing processes, while parallelism is defined as the simultaneous execution
of (possibly related) computations. These two concepts are related yet have
completely different meanings: concurrency is about dealing with lots of things
at once, while parallelism is about doing lots of things at once. I hope that
this talk will make it easier to understand and effectively use these two
principles in Software Engineering.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
2'>                        </span>12:25-12:50
--- Geoffrey Tucker<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Title:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:.5in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>The
Rise of Multi-factor Authentication [<a href="talk-Tucker-MultiFactorAuth.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>As
computers become more powerful and encryption algorithms slowly become
outdated, password security becomes increasingly more important. To maximize
one's security, it is imperative to choose a long password with symbols,
numbers, as well as upper and lower case letters. However, for the common user,
long passwords are rarely chosen as they are easy to forget and take longer to
type out. Multi-factor authentication provides a profound increase in security
for common users who like to use their shorter passwords, as well as for more
advanced users who seek to maximize their security beyond having a strong password.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><o:p> </o:p></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Title:</span></b><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:4'>                                                </span>Big
Data Management: Past, Present, and Future [<a
href="talk-Magruder-Big-Data-Management.pdf">PDF</a>]<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>Abstract:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:2.0in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-2.0in'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>                                                </span>In
this talk, I will discuss the history of technological systems for managing
“Big Data”, the inception of the field, and the current activities
and architectures related to developing such systems.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Although Big Data has progressed
massively since the need for management systems became most pressing in the
late 1970s, many architectural issues still remain.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Recently developed components and layers
within data management systems are being used to tackle these challenges posed
by the current understanding of the Big Data field, and this talk covers
professional opinions on what are the most important open challenges in the
field are and the most promising solutions for the data community to pursue to
ensure the most efficient data management systems.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
